titlePage.docImprint: Vol. Xxiv — no.38 Richmond, Va. Friday, February 13, 1863 price one Cent

div1.head:
Richmond Dispatch
by Cowardin & Hammersley.
div1.p:
the Daily Dispatch is served to subscribers at six and A Quarter cents per Week, payable to the Carrier weekly.
Price for mailing, $4 a year, or $2.50 for six months, in advance.
the Semi-Weekly Dispatch is issued every Tuesday and Friday at $2.00, in advance.
the Weekly Dispatch is issued every Friday, and mailed to subscribers at $1 per annum.
Advertisements published until forbid, will be charged 50 cents per square of eight lines for the first insertion, and 25 cents for each continuance

div3.head: The bombardment of Galveston.
div3.p:
The bombardment of Galveston by the Brooklyn and four other Federal steamers, was commenced on the 10th ult. The first day 107 shells were fired, several of them striking the hospital in which the Federals were who were wounded at the recapture of the city by our forces.
A goat killed was the only casualty in the city.
The next day two of the steamers left.

div3.head: From Middle Tennessee.
div3.p: The Winchester (Tenn.) Bulletin, of Sunday, furnishes some items of interest from Gen. Johnston's command:

On Friday evening the enemy made an unsuccessful attempt to advance with another foraging party in force.
Our infantry were ordered eight miles to the front to support the cavalry, and 'tis thought that we had repulsed them with considerable loss on their part.
Twelve prisoners taken a few days since, stated they were nearly starved.--The first thing they asked for was something to eat.
Eighty of Woolford's men deserted and joined us a few days since.

Brig-Gen. Hardin Helm, of Ky., is to take command of the lamented Hanson's brigade.
The voltigner system is to be adopted in the mounting of the brigade.

div3.head: More of the capture of Arkansas Post.
div3.p: A gentleman recently from the West of the Mississippi, furnishes the Grenada Appeal some additional intelligence of the capture of Arkansas Post:

Gen. Holmes was advised of the intention of the enemy, and immediately ordered reinforcements forward.
They pushed on as rapidly as possible, and had arrived within a few miles of the position when they became advised of the surrender.
Had they reached the Post in reason they would, it is believed, with the aid of the garrison, have been able to repulse the haseigers; but they were not strong enough to attack them in the defences — consequently they fell back.
The forces at the Post made a most gallant resistance.
The truth is, they were but poorly supplied, but with the means at hand they held the foe at bay until almost all their artillery were dismounted, and were surrounded before surrendering.
The force of the enemy was overwhelming.
The people of Arkansas are making greater exertions, and the military authorities are much more active, in making preparations to prevent any further success of the enemy.

div3.head: How New Orleans was taken — a Yankee opinion of the supineness of our naval officers.
div3.p:
The capture of the Harriet Lane has brought to light a correspondence thowing that New Orleans might easily have been held by the Confederates and that the dash of the Federal vessels was a last and desperate move on the part of the bombarding forces, the success of which surprised even its projectors themselves.
The Houston Telegraph of the 16th ult., contains a letter written by Commander Wainwright, of the steamer Harriet Lane, to Commander D. D. Porter, relating to the Confederate defence of New Orleans, and how that city was taken by the Federals.
It will be seen from the extract we give below that Commander Wainwright regards their success as owing mainly to the "supineness" of our naval officers:

div4.head:
U. S. Steamship Harriet Lane.,
ship Island, June 1st, 1862.
div4.p:
--In reply to your communication of the 29th ult., I have to state that on the afternoon of April 22d a signal was made from the flag ship Hartford for all commanding officers to repair on board.
Though not positive that the signal was intended to apply to the officers attached to the mortar flotilla, I determined to present myself in obedience thereto, which I accordingly did. I found assembled all the commanding officers of the fleet, with the exception of those attached to the mortar flottile, myself being the only representative of that branch of the squadron.
Upon repairing to the cabin of the flag-officer, I was laughingly told that I was looked upon as an outsider, and that the signal was not meant for me. Perhaps it would have been more delicate in me to have retired but as I felt that the object of the meeting had a common interest for all, I determined to remain, supposing that no objection to my presence could exist admitting that there was no necessity for it.

The flag officer then proceeded to state the reason why the officers had been summoned, which was to give his plan for passing the forts, and the disposition be proposed to make of the forces under his command.
He premised by saying that Capt. Porter had submitted a plan of operations which embraced ideas similar to his own, and with which he entirely agreed.
He then continued to state his plans, and invited the opinion of the officers there assembled.
The prevailing feeling seemed to be adverse to making the attempt to pass the forts at that time; that it was premature; that the forts had not been sufficiently reduced by the fire of the mortar vessels, and that the risk of the loss of many of the vessels was too great to be run. --The question was freely asked, why the mortar vessels could not continue the bombardment for a length of time; the idea of which appeared to be rather indefinite, unless it was expected that the reduction of the forts should be owing to the force of the mortar vessels entirely, when the ships would be able to pass in comparative safety.

The flag officer said he agreed in the main with what had been said; but that Capt. Porter urged very strongly the attempt being made, not only on the ground of its probable success, but from the fact that the fire of the mortar vessels could not be sustained for a much longer period; that the ammunition was becoming scarce and difficult of supply, the vessels shaken by the constant concussion, and the men fagged out with a continued bombardment, which had already lasted for more than four days and three nights; on these accounts the flag officer said he had determined to make the attack the same night. * * * * *

In conclusion, you ask my opinion whether you were justified by results in advocating so strenuously the advance of the fleet, and what might and would have been the result had your counsel, which was deemed premature, been disregarded.
Having been more intimately associated with you, and probably more conversant with your plans and expectations than any other in the squadron, I am enabled to say that the brilliant result most completely vindicated the wisdom of your counsel and the soundness of your views.
By the light of knowledge obtained subsequent to the surrender of the forts, it is plain that delay in the attack would have been fatal to us. Had the defence been as vigorously and gallantly conducted by the naval portion of the forces opposed to us as it was by the army, the chances are that the mortar vessels would have been obliged to retire before the fire of the iron-clad battery Louisiana, which was to have taken up baraking position below the water battery of Fort St. Phillip, and under the protection of the guns of both forts.
Fortunately for us, the supineness of the rebel naval officers left us undisturbed; but it cannot be conceived had the attack been delayed a day or so longer, that the enemy would have fulled to make use of so formidable an adjunct to his means of defence.
div4.closer:
I am, with great respect your ob't serv't,
(Signed) J. M. Wainwright,
Lieutenant Commanding.
Commander Daniel D. Porter, U. S. N., commanding Mortar Flotilla.

div4.p:
While on this subject we give an extract from the Message of Governor Moore, of Louisiana, to the Legislature, regarding the same affair.
After giving a history of the efforts to prepare for a naval attack on the forts, etc., he says:

q.p:
The Louisiana was at length started for the forts on the afternoon of the 20th, but with her prow unadjusted, her armament incomplete, and her machinery untested.
On the same day I had telegraphed to Gen. Duncan, offering to supply whatever was in my power, and suggesting the use of sand bags for the protection of the fort, which I offered to furnish.
He at once accepted the offer, and the following morning I dispatched a steamer with five thousand to the fort.
On the next succeeding day I wrote to the Chief Officers of State, suggesting that the records of their offices and all the archives of State be put in a condition to admit of their removal at a few hours' notice.

div4.p:
A telegram from Gen. Duncan at 45 minutes past 10 A. M., of the 23d, gave an encouraging and hopeful account of their condition, considering that "from 22,000 to 25,000 thirteen inch mortar shells" had been fired by the enemy, of which "thousands had fallen within the fort" Fearing that this dispatch, which Gen. D. had requested to be published, was intended mainly to allay the apprehensions of the citizens, and being informed by one of my officers whom I had sent to the forts to ascertain their condition that they were seriously injured, and that the navy had left them no assistance, I immediately telegraphed the General a request to inform me "of the exact condition of things." His answer at 8 P. M., of the same day, was, "the navy has lent us no assistance whatever up to this hour, and we cannot get them to place the Louisiana in position.
They say they will do so to- morrow night.
I am much obliged for your kindly offer, but we want nothing.
The fear we have is that in a general engagement some of the vessels may get by." "To-morrow night" was too late.
Ten hours after that dispatch was received the fear that some of the vessels would get by was reached.

div3.head: Recruiting for Gen. Bragg's army.
div3.p:
--A Volunteer and Conscript Bureau has been formed for Gen. Bragg's army, with Gen. G. J. Pillow as its chief.
Regiments have been temporarily and solidated in order to get commissioned officers to serve in this department; and already has General Pillow detailed and dispatched a thousand to their respective homes to gather up struggler, deserters, and conscripts, to fill the depleted ranks.

div3.head: Northern dates of the 9th instant are received.
div3.p:
--In the Senate on the 7th, Turple, of Indians, and Richardson, of Illinois made strong Northwestern anti-abolition speeches.
The former characterised Lincoln as a tyrant, and said he would have no subjects west of the Alleghenies.

At a meeting in New York on the 8th, at which Gen. Scott presided, General Burnside made a speech, plainly intimating demoralization of the Yankee army.
He predicted several important battles soon, and counselled support of Lincoln.

A dispatch from Washington says that there is no enemy in force at Fredericksburg.
Most of the rebel soldiers have been sent to the Blackwater or to Vicksburg, the only force left behind being about 15,000 men, an ample number to prevent the passage of the Rappahannock at the present season.
From deserters and other sources it has been ascertained that the rebel railroad communications are perfect.
In 72 hours the entire army of the enemy can be transferred from any point in the South to Fredericksburg, so that they can well afford to spare a great body of their army from our front.

During the past week, says the dispatch, the President determined upon recalling McClellan to the command of the army.
Upon the announcement being made in a Cabinet Council there was a great flurry.
Secretary Change at once threatened to resign, as did also the rest of the radical members of the Cabinet.
For this and other reasons the President declined to make a change for the present.
Within two weeks, however, there is scarcely a doubt but that the command of the army will be read or bill, Gen. McClellan.
The appointment of Gen. Hocker to the command of the Army of the Potomac is merely temporary.
It was made against the judgment of the President and even of the Secretary of War.
His soldierly qualities are not doubted, but his ability to handle such an immense body of men is seriously questioned by his friends.

Nothing of importance is expected to be done at Vicksburg for at least thirty days. It will take that time to complete the canal and bring our forces effectually to bear against the rebel strongholds — It may be, however, that circumstances may precipitate a battle, but the general impression is that it will require a month at least to capture the place.

div4.head: Federal account of the naval fight at Charleston.
div4.p:
The New York papers contain full accounts of the fight at Charleston.
The rebels attacked the Mercedita first. One ram struck her on the water edge kooling her over, and at the same time firing a shot which entered one of her port holes, causing the death of three persons, including a gunner, by a shot and steam.
The ram then hailed the Mercedita, and Captain Stellwagen lowered one of his small boats, alter leaving one of the plugs out, allowing the water to enter it. The ram answered to our hail by replying that she was the Confederate ram Palmetto State.
Do you surrender!
This was repeated three times Capt. Stellwagen replying at each inquiry "I am in a sinking condition."The rebels answered," God d — n you go to h-- if you do not surrender we will blow you out of the water.
Send your boat aboard." The boat which Capt. Stellwagen lowered then conveyed his Lieutenant Executive officer to the side of the rebel ram, and the officers asked to be admitted on board, which was refused.
The Lieutenant then repeated Capt. Stellwagen's statement, that we were in a sinking condition to which the rebel officer replied, "you cannot sink lower than the rails; we cannot take you on board."

The officer then gave his parole as demanded, and returned to his ship.
The rebels were thus successfully deceived as to the condition of the Mercedita, thinking she was in a sinking condition.
She laid in shoal water, and hence their reply that she could not sink deeper than her rails.

The rams steamed towards the Keystone State, and sent a shot through her steam drum, causing the death of twenty-one persons--twelve by the shot and nine by scalding with steam.
Fifteen were wounded and are lying at Port Royal, some in a precarious condition.
In the meantime the U. S. gunboat Housatonic engaged the other ram, driving her away at 6 ½ o'clock in the morning, at which time both rams left the scene and proceeded to Charleston.

During the attack on our fleet the Princess Royal, which was tied near the Housatonic, and was the chief object of prize on both sides, succeeded in getting off mainly through the energies of Third Assistant Engineer Thornton, who plied into her fire all the inflammable material at hand.
The escape is chiefly owing to his endeavors as well as her safe arrival at this port, not withstanding the severe gale which prevailed during the passage from Port Royal.
Although the coal was the anthracite with which our navy is supplied she made ten knots an hour on her trip with case, in the heaviest storm.
Her usual rate is fifteen knots.

The Mercedita steamed down to Port Royal, escaping with only one of her boilers injured.
She arrived safely at Port Royal, towed by the Memphis.
The rebel statement that the Federal fleet had entirely disappeared from before Charleston is entirely unsustained by the facts.
The fleet consisted of the following vessels: Unadella, Housatonia, Augusta, Quaker City, Keystone State, and Mercedita, with the pilot-boats Blunt, Memphis, and other vessels.
During the day time our blockading fleet are not particular as to being at the station, and on the day of their assault most of the vessels sailed towards the Keystone State to ascertain her condition, and whether she wanted any assistance.
This may account for their apparent absence at the time of the visit of the foreign Consuls, as mentioned by the rebel papers.
Our vessels as usual resumed their positions.
At dark the next day the new Ironsides arrived to reinforce the blockade.

div4.head: The second fight at Fort Donelson.
div4.p: Rosecrans sent the following report of the second battle of Fort Donelson:

opener.salute: To Maj.-Gen. H. W. Halteck, General in Chief, Washington:

div5.p:
The rebels, Wheeler, Forrest, Wharton, and Woodward, attacked Fort Donelson yesterday at 1 o'clock P. M., with 4 000 men and eight pieces of artillery.
We have 800 men in the fort under Col. A. C. Harding.
The rebels charged the fortifications several times, but were repulsed by our artillery and infantry, with great loss.
The enemy, as usual, before and after the fight, demanded a surrender offering to spare life if accepted.
Col. Harding replied that he was ready for all consequences.
The enemy's loss in killed was over 100, and in prisoners 300. The forces under Col. Lowe, from Fort Henry, are pursuing the rebels, and others have been sent to intercept their retreat.
Our loss is 12 killed and 30 wounded.

div4.head: Further accounts.
div4.p: The New York World has later accounts from Nashville, to the 7th.
Gen. Davis's division, with cavalry and artillery, has been sent to intercept the rebels who made the attack on Fort Donelson, under the command of Morgan.
The same paper reports that 135 rebels had been buried by the Yankees at Fort Donelson. --The rebel Gen. Forrest was wounded.

Nashville, Feb. 7.--Our victory over the rebels at Fort Donelson was complete and decisive.
Col. Lowe, of the 5th Iowa, was in command of the forces at the fort.
When our informant left, 145 rebels had been buried, 100 prisoners were taken, and more were being brought in. The rebels retreated towards Charlotte.

div4.head: Miscellaneous.
div4.p: The Yankee papers are accusing Hooker of drunkenness.

Gold, on the 7th, in New York, was 158½ @ 157½.
Sterling Exchange 173 @174.

div3.head: A Bad State of "Enthusiasm" among Federal troops.--
div3.p:
--A correspondent of the Atlanta Confederacy says that a body of 150 Illinois soldiers were captured near Manchester, Tenn., a few days since, who made no resistance whatever, and only asked to be paroled and informed by what route they could get home without meeting any Federal soldiers.
The following paragraph, from the Boston (Mass.) Post, gives some idea of the "enthusiasm" prevailing among the Kentucky troops:

Kentucky has given over 40 Union regiments to the Union armies, and they have borne the brunt of battle shoulder to shoulder with the bravest; but under the effect of the radical programme they are dwindling away by resignations and desertions from full regiments to mere companies.
The 26th Ky., which distinguished itself at Shiloh and captured a rebel battery, is reduced to 120 men. Another regiment advertises over 250 deserters, and the average desertions from all are nearly up to that number.
The 16th, which fought so desperately at Perryville, and lost all its field officers--Col. Pope, Lieut. Col. Jewitt, and Major Campbelt--has lost nine other commissioned officers by resignation Captain M. C. Taylor, Lieuts. Winloch and McGrath and others have quit the service.
There are not less than 100 deserters from the 3d 15th, 23d, and other Kentucky regiments, now lurking about Newport, Ky. A squad of 18 cavalrymen, in one body, was seen a day or two ago not far from that place, and efforts have been made to arrest them, but without success.

div3.head: Couldn't stand it.
div3.p:
--The Shelbyville (Tenn.) Banner says that Col. Moore, of Illinois, who was ordered by Gen. Mitchell to destroy the property of Capt. Dick McCann, has resigned his commission in the Federal army rather than again be of such brutality.
In justify to Col. that his conduct, in executing the commands of his infamous superior, was characterized by great gentility.

div3.head: Held as a hostage.
div3.p: --Assistant Surgeon Jas. C. Green, of Danville, Va., recently captured by the Abolitionists, is now confined at Washington and held as a hostage for the infamous Dr. Bucker.

div4.p: --The Senate met at 12 o'clock, Mr. Hunter in the chair.

Mr. Clay, of Ala., offered a resolution inquiring into the propriety of adopting "a cavalier" as the seal of the Confederate States, and of taking as a model the pedestrian statue of Washington in the Capitol Square of Richmond, as it appears from an eastern view.
Adopted.
Mr. Sparrow, of La., submitted the following resolution, which, on motion of Mr. Oldham, of Texas, was referred to the Committee on Commerce:

Whereas The several Confederate States contiguous to the Mississippi river have, by ordinances of their respective.
Conventions, recognized the right of all friendly people living upon the tributaries thereof to its free navigation; and whereas the Provisional Government of the Confederate States did by an act approved February 25th, 1861, declare "the peaceful navigation of the Mississippi river free to the citizens of any of the States upon its borders, or upon the borders of its navigable tributaries;" and whereas the ordinances of the said several States and the act of the Provisional Government touching this important and serious question are eminently right and just: Now therefore, be it.

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives of the Confederate States of America. That this Confederacy does now and will at all times maintain and support the right to the free navigation of the Mississippi river, as declared and set forth in the said act of the Provisional Government.
Mr. Henry, of Tenn., by leave introduced a bill to repeal an act for the establishment of places of rendezvous for enrolled men, which was referred to the Military Committee.

Mr. Hill of Ga., from the Judiciary Committee, reported a bill to amend the several acts prescribing the mode of publishing the laws and resolutions of the Confederate States, which was placed on the calendar.
The bill from the House to prohibit punishment by whipping in the army was taken up in order and on motion of Mr. Sparrow, referred to the Committee on Military Affairs.
The bill organizing the Supreme Court was postponed until Tuesday next.

The bill reported from the Military Committee to amend the exemption act being up Mr. Phelan moved to lay it upon the table for the purpose of taking up for action the House bill "to repeal certain clauses of the exemption act relative to the exemption of overseers.
Mr. Hill, of Ga., thought that the exemption of overseers in the manner provided in the existing law was necessary and proper.
Mr. Simms, of Ky., opposed the exemption of overseers, because he regarded it class legislation.
Mr. Orr, of S. C., enforced the views of Mr. Hill in favor of the policy of exempting overseers, and was followed by Mr. Wigfall on the same side.
After further discussion by Mr. Burnett, of Ky., the consideration of the pending motion was postponed, and the Senate adjourned at 3 o'clock.

div4.head: House of Representatives.
div4.p: --House met at 12 o'clock, and was opened with prayer by Rev. Dr. Burrows.

The Speaker laid before the House a communication from the Secretary of the Treasury, relative to the mode of making appropriations for ministers and agents who reside abroad.
Referred to Committee of Ways and Means.
Mr. Lyons, of Va. moved that the House go into secret session; which was not agreed to.

Resolutions Introduced and Referred.--By Mr. H. W. Bruce, of Ky.: A resolution to inquire into the expediency of giving matrons in hospitals commutation for board, lodging, fuel, and lights, in lieu of the same.

By Mr. Conrad, of La.: A resolution that the President be requested to inform this House what real estate if any, has been sold under the provisions of an act entitled "An act for the sequestration of the property and affect of alien enemies, and for the indemnity of citizens of the Confederate States, and persons aiding the same in the present war; and what amount has been paid into the Treasury arising from such sales.
By the same: A resolution that the Committee on Military Affairs inquire into the expediency of prohibiting the detail of officers of the line to serve in the staff.

By Mr. Dupre, of La.: A resolution that the Committee on the Medical Department be requested to inquire into the propriety of not receiving any more sick or wounded soldiers in the hospitals in Richmond, until those now confined in the hospitals shall be discharged or furloughed, and until said hospitals are thoroughly cleansed and fumigated, and to fix a time either by legislation or otherwise, when the sick and wounded may be admitted anew in the Richmond hospitals.

Bills Introduced and Referred.--By Mr. Helt, of Ga.: A bill further to provide for the public and local defence of the Confederate States.
Referred to Committee on Military Affairs.

By Mr. Clarke, of Ga.: A bill to regulate the granting of furloughs and discharges in hospitals.
Referred.

By Mr. H. W. Bruce, of Ky.: A bill to provide a uniform currency.
Referred to Committee of Ways and Means.

By Mr. Dupre, of La.: A bill to amend an act entitled an act to provide for the safe custody, printing, publication, and distribution of the laws and to provide for the appointment of an addition all clerk in the Department of Justice.
Referred to the Committee on Printing.
By Mr. McRae, of Miss.: A bill to provide for exemptions from military service.
Mr. McRae moved to suspend the rules, with a view to considering the bill at once; but the motion was lost, and the bill referred to the Military Committee.

By Mr. Davidson, of N. C.: A bill to provide for the payment of all sums due to soldiers from N. Carolina, for services rendered after they were received into the State service and before they were turned over to the Confederate States.
Referred to Military Committee.

By Mr. Smith, of N. C.: A bill to alter and amend an act entitled "An act for the sequestration of the estates, property, and effects of alien enemies, and for indemnity of citizens of the Confederate States, and persons aiding the same in the existing war with the United States." Referred to the Judiciary Committee.
Secret Session.--Mr. Lyons, of Va, renewed his motion that the House go into secret session.
Mr. Goode, of Va, called the ayes and noes on this motion, which were ordered, and resulted — ayes 20, noes

The Impressment Bill.--The special order, the bill introduced by Mr. Holcombe, of Va. from the Judiciary Committee, to authorize and regulate impressments of private property for the use of the army and other military purposes, was taken up.
Mr. Lyons, of Va, submitted a substitute for the entire bill, which was ordered to be printed.

Mr. Holcombe being entitled to the floor, addressed the House in support of the bill reported from the committee.
At the conclusion of his remarks.
Mr. Lyons of Va., moved that the further consideration of the bill be postponed until to- morrow, at 1 o'clock, that amendmen's offered might be printed and laid before the House.
This motion was lost by the following vote: ayes 29, noes 39; so the House refused to postpone.
Mr. Lyons then addressed the House in favor of the 1st and 2d sections of his amendment as a substitute for the 1st section of the committee's bill.
Mr. Lyons was followed by Mr. Dargan, of Ala., in a speech on the general subject of impressment, and in favor of the original bill in the main.
On motion, the further consideration of the bill was postponed till 1 o'clock to-morrow.
On motion of Mr. Davidson, of N. C., the House adjourned.

Senate.--The Senate assembled at 12 M, the President in the chair.
Prayer by Rev. Mr. Pettigrew, of the Church of the Disciples.

div4.head: Disposition of House Bills
div4.p:
--The act concerning the estate of John Haskins, a lunatic, was laid on the table; the act for the relief of Thos Littleton, jailor of London county, was passed; the act to provide for the appointment of general agents and storekeepers for counties and corporations, was read twice and referred to Committee on Courts of justice; the Committee on Confederate Relations, to whom was referred the budget of correspondence between the State and Confederate Governments, touching the enlargement of the rights and the infraction of the laws of the Commonwealth, by persons held as prisoners of war, made a report, and at their request were discharged from the further consideration of the subject.
The same committee, to whom was referred the subject of the arrest of civilians by military authority, asked to be discharged from the further consideration of the second and third resolutions of the series, the first having been adopted by the Senate.

The joint resolution from the House, calling for a joint committee of eleven from the House of Delegates and seven from the Senate, to take into consideration the subject of general and special elections, etc, was concurred in and the same reported back to the House.

div4.head: Bill Introduced.
div4.p: --A bill providing for the more effectual and speedy transportation of freight and travel between Richmond and Petersburg.

The Salt Committee introduced a preamble and resolution in relation to the supply of salt to be obtained from the salines of Washington and Smyth counties citing the inadequacy of the machinery and transportation as furnished by the testimony of the officers of the Virginia and Tennessee Railroad, and the impossibility of supplying it without the detail of a sufficient number of hands by the Confederate Government for their workshops and for preparing lumber; and suggesting a committee of three on the part of the House and two on the part of the Senate to confer with the Confederate Government on the matter.
The resolution was laid over under the rules.

div4.head: Resolutions of inquiry.
div4.p: --By Mr. Whittle: Enacting a law to respite the execution of such citizens of this State or of the United States as may be in the hands of the authorities of this State for trial for capital offences committed within the State, and for which they may be convicted, till such time as may hereafter be prescribed by law. By Mr. Douglass; Granting relief to Wm. T. Clark, of the county of Essex, from incurred by him under the act to prevent the unnecessary consumption of grain by distillers other manufacturers of liquors.

Mr. Robertson offered a resolution looking to a final adjournment, resolving by the Senate, with the concurrence of the House of Delegates, that when the General Assembly adjourn on the 25th inst, it shall stand adjourned

The bill to increase the pay of certain officials of the Commonwealth was taken up, discussed, and amended, and laid over until to-morrow.
Adjourned.

div4.head: House of Delegates.
div4.p: --The House met at 12 o'clock. Prayer by Rev. Dr. Jeter.

Mr. McCamant, from the Committee on Salt, reported a bill, stating that the testimony of the officers of the Virginia and Tennessee Railroad had convinced the committee that, for the want of machinery, etc., it was impossible for them to furnish sufficient transportation to the citizens of Virginia and other States of the Confederacy dependent on the Washington and Smyth county salines for salt, without the detail of a sufficient member of hands from the Confederate Government for their workshops, and preparing lumber and asking the appointment of a joint committee on the part of the two Houses to confer with the Confederate authorities with reference to such detail, and urge upon them in the strongest terms the necessity of making the detail desired.
The report was agreed to.

Mr. Wynne called up the bill enlarging the powers of the Council of Richmond, which was agreed to and the bill passed.
The following is its provisions:

Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Virginia, That the Council of the city of Richmond be and the same is hereby author and suppressions and unlawful assembles in the city; to suppress gunning and gambling houses, tippling and tippling houses and to prevent or regulate the sale of spirituous and liquors within the said city, and around the same to the boundaries to which the jurisdiction of its corporation courts or officers of police extends in criminal cases; and for the purpose of executing the powers and authority hereby vested in said Council, the said Council may enact ordinances and impose penalties for the violation thereof, not exceeding five hundred dollars and imprisonment not exceeding three months; may authorize and empower the proper officers and police of the city to seize such liquors, sold or kept for sale, for the use of the city, and to shut up the houses in which such liquors are so sold or kept for sale, and arrest the persons who shall sell, or keep for sale or purchase, the said liquors, in violation of said ordinances, and hold them in custody until they shall give security for their good behavior in such penalty, not exceeding one thousand dollars, as the justice before whom they are taken shall prescribe.
And the said officers and police shall have the same powers and authority in discharging their duties under said ordinances as State officers have in cases of breaches of the peace.

II.
The said Council may organize and establish an armed police, and appoint such officers thereof as the Council may deem expedient; and the said officers shall be accountable to, and under the supervision and control of, the Council, or such other body or officer as the Council may prescribe.

III.
This act shall be in farce from its passage.
Mr. West moved to suspend the rules to take up bill No. 49, relative to enlarging the powers of Circuit Courts relative to attachments against nonresidents.

Mr. Hopkins, in view of the frequency with which the rules were suspended, called for the ayes and noes on this motion as a test question whether the House intended to abide by rules heretofore adopted for its government.
The roll was called and the motion defeated — ayes 16, noes 56.

On motion of Mr. Baskerville, the bill authorizing the sale of the Roanoke Valley Railroad was taken up, upon which quite an animated discussion took place, participated in by Messrs Baskerville, Forbes, Anderson of Rockbridge, Robertson of Richmond city, and others.
The debate was brought to a close by a call for the previous question, and the main question being put, the bill was passed — ayes 74, noes 15.

Mr. Flood submitted a resolution, which was agreed to, inquiring into the expediency of assuming Virginia's quota of the Confederate war tax for the fiscal year; and if expedient, to further inquire into the best means of paying it with the least burden to the Commonwealth.

Mr. Marye submitted a resolution, which was agreed to, appointing a select committee of five, whose duty it shall be to inquire and report to the House whether the use and control of the railroads in the State exercized by the Confederate Government may not be so regulated as the better to secure the transportation of commodities for private use, whenever said road is not in use by the Government, and empowering them to send for officers and others for examination.
On motion of Mr. Bradford the House adjourned.

div3.head: Further from Europe.
div3.p: --The steamer Hansa has reached New York, with Liverpool dates to the 22d ultimo:
A public meeting in Liverpool endorsed Lincoln's emancipation policy, and proposed to take the sense of the British nation on the war in America.
In a dispatch to Lord Russell, from the British Consul in Charleston, he says the cotton in the South amounts to 4,250,000 bales. The Consul at Savannah says 3,500,000.

Public speaking on American affairs is still going on. Milven Gibson, M. P., has appeared, opposing the recognition of the Confederate States, as leading to war with the United States, and cutting off the breadstuff supply of England.
Mr. Baresford, M. P., has also delivered a speech, urging the recognition of the South.
The London Times thinks Napoleon's Forey letter as dangerous to the Confederates as it is to the United States.

div3.head: A cross in the sky.
div3.p:
--A well defined cross was seen in the sky a few nights since.
A correspondent of the Wilmington (N. C.) Journal, writing from Kinston, N. C., gives the following description of the phenomena:

The moon rose cloudless.
At a little before seven o'clock two bright spots, some twelve degrees, [Qr.
in extent!] were visible, one North and the other South, and immediately thereafter a cross was seen in the heavens, the moon joining the four arms of the cross.
About half-past 8 o'clock the Northern light went out, but the cross and the spot to the South remained until past ten, when I retired.
Can any one tell when the cross has appeared before since the days of Constantine, when the letters I. H. S. accompanied the sign?

div3.head: The Yankees at Baton Rouge.
div3.p:
--In the early part of this week a negro regiment arrived at Baton Rouge, which caused quite a stir among some of the Federal officers.
They held an indignation meeting and fifty of them resigned their commissions in consequence of the amalgamation.
Yesterday morning an order was read placing the Yankee officers on an equality with the negroes, and requiring all citizens and Federal officers to respect and obey the black officers.
From all we can hear it seems great dissatisfaction prevails among the troops, and the officers are unwilling to risk an attack with such rebellious spirits.
They know the character of our troops here and feel their inability, in their present disorganized state, to cope with the thoroughly disciplined and veteran troops of Port Hudson.
The Essex, a sloop and two transports were at Baton Rouge at last accounts.--Pointa Cupee (La.) Echo.

div3.head: Cheap washing.
div3.p: --T. C. Hobson, of Greensboro', Alabama, who has witnessed an economical and gratifying experiment in the washing line, gives it to the public thus:

With a quantity of Buckeye root, washed and sliced, a tub fill of hot water was readily and rapidly made into "suda." In this mixture a number of various colored woollen garments were speedily washed fires from all dirt and all stain, without the least perceptible injury of any of the textures.
On the contrary, the washing had the effect of fixing and brightening all the colors.--Even those prints that fade in water alone were left intact and as beautiful as new. The mixture was allowed to become lukewarm before immersing the clothes, and two tubs full were used in the process, carrying the articles washed from one into the other.
I knew this fact many years ago, but this is the first time that I have seen it tried.
It washes silk as nicely as it does woollen goods.

div3.head: Notice to Creditors.
div3.p: --All persons having claims against Mordecal Carnell, dec'd, will present them to me properly authenticated, for payment, and all those indebted will please make payment to me without delay, in order to a speedy settlement of the estate.

div3.head: Escape from prison.
div3.p:
--A man named William Campbell, said to be a member of the New Orleans Washington Artillery, who was confined in Castle Thunder for desertion, escaped therefrom between eight and ten o'clock on Wednesday night. Campbell, who had been but recently arrested after two previous escapes from the same prison, was securely ironed hands and feet, and in a room by himself.
His escape without aid, therefore, seems impossible.

div3.head: Visit to a prison.
div3.p:
--Hon. London C. Hoynes, of Tennessee, and other members of Congress, on Tuesday visited and inspected Castle Thunder, with whose cleanliness and order they expressed themselves highly pleased.
While at the prison Mr. Haynes was shown the apartment allotted to domestic traitors, (or so called Union men) In it were a number of men from East Tennessee.--Many of these were recognized by the honorable gentleman, who, after a kindly greeting, briefly addressed them in language that brought tears to the eyes of many of them.

div3.head: Test of transportation.
div3.p:
--In peace times a barrel and its contents, of the usual weight could be brought from Norfolk to Richmond for twenty five cents. Now one dollar and fifty cents is demanded by the railroad to bring a barrel from the White House to Richmond.
These rates operate to swell the price of various articles of food brought from the lower country.
Oysters, which now command from $5 to $6 per gallon, would be sold by the venders at half these prices and money be made, could they get transportation at reasonable rates.

div3.head: Important to officers.
div3.p: --Army officers now absent from their commands have been notified by the Adjutant General that they have thirty days from February 7th, in which to render account for such absence, and on failure, their names will be erased from the army rolls.

div3.head: Court Proceedings.
div3.p:
Supreme Court.--The following decisions have been rendered during this week by the Judges of this Court.
Present Hon. John J. Allen, William Daniel, Richard C. L. Moncure, and Wm. J. Robertson:

Short vs. the Commonwealth.
Argued by Dan'l B. Lucas and James Alfred Jones for the plaintiff, and John Randolph Tucker, Attorney-General, for the Commonwealth Judgment of the Court of Hustings of the city of Richmond affirmed.

Slater vs. the Commonwealth.
Argued by Wm. W. Crump for the plaintiff, and John Randolph Tucker, Attorney General, for the Commonwealth Judgment of the Court of Hustings of the city of Richmond affirmed.

Ferguston vs. the Commonwealth.
Argued by Wm. T. Joynes for the plaintiff, and Jno Randolph Tucker, Attorney General, for the Commonwealth.
Judgment of the Circuit Court of Chesterfield co. affirmed.

Nicholas vs. Tuck, &c. Argued by Beverly R. Wellford, Jr, for the appellant, and James Alfred Jones for the appellees.
Decree of the Circuit Court of the city of Richmond reversed.

Jones's adm'r and others vs. Osborn and others.
Argued by McFarland & Roberts for the appellants, and August & Randolph, Jas, Alfred Jones, Arthur A. Morson, and B. R. Wellford, Jr., for the appellees.
Decree of the Circuit Court of the city of Richmond reversed.

Note.--Joseph G. Furgusses shot and killed Wm. Jewett, engineer on the Clover Hill Railroad, sometime in 1832.
The evidence of the fact was wholly circumstantial, but he was convicted and sentenced to be hung.
James Slater was sent to the State's penitentiary for ten years by the Hustings Court for cutting and stabbing Wm. Clarke in Butchestown, thereby causing his death.

Albert G. Short, a North Carolina soldier, shot without cause James T. Gray, a comrade, near the Old Market, killing him instantly.
The jury sent him to the Penitentiary for only three years, giving him the benefit of his assertion that he did not know the gun was loaded.
The Supreme Court would not interfere with any of these sentences.
Hustings Court, Thursday,February 12th. --Recorder James K. Caskle presiding.

John Boyd was examined for stealing $28 out of the pocket of Orman M. Hancock, a soldier, near the Varieties Theatre, on Franklin street, and was committed for trial before Judge Lyons, for grand larceny.
It will be remembered that after the arrest and conveyance to the cage of this prisoner, some of his pals lingered around the Station-House and and shot at two of the city watch, whom they imagined had been instrumental in conveying their comrade to the lock-up.
The cases of presentment against Jerome Diggs and others for exhibiting fare bank, was continued until the next term of the Court.

Andrew Rogers and A. Mason, who swindled Wm. M. Allen and Wm. A. Charles each out of $1,260 by furnishing them bogus substitutes which, as pretended officers of the 6th regiment, they received into an imaginary company, were examined for the offence, and were committed to stand their final trial before Judge Lyons for felony.
A nolle prosequi was entered in the case of Daniel Logan, alles Augustus Taylor, who was indicted for stealing two one dollar Confederate Treasury notes.
Wm. McIntyre was tried for stealing one pair of shoes from Michael Golden, and being found guilty, was sentenced to thirty days imprisonment in the city jail.

A nolle presequi was entered in the case of Wm. Henry Ross and John Robertson, free negroes, charged with robbing Alfred, a slave, of $22--They were sent again before the Mayor to be examined for larceny.
Mayor's Court, Thursday, February 12th. --John Webb was arraigned for stealing $11 from T. D. Wolfe, and remanded for indictment by the Hustings Court Grant Jury.
James, slave of Charles E. Anderson, was arraigned for fighting in the streets, and being a small buy, was set apart for a slight licking.
Thomas N. Dobas was required to give security to keep the peace for being disorderly in the Theatre and assaulting Chas. Epps.
Lewis, slave of Wm. Greaner, was examined for stealing a pocket-book from Wm. Page, containing $30, and was ordered 30 lashes for the offence.
The case of Alfred, slave of Nathan Hollings-worth, charged with stealing $460 from Stephen, a slave, was continued.

Anderson, slave of Joseph DeCourt, and Aaron, slave of Joseph Bryce, were charged with being runaways.
Both said they belonged to General Smith's staff.
The Mayor ordered each of these officers 10 lashes.

div3.head: Prospectus.
div3.p:
--The publication of the "Sentinel" newspaper, which has been suspended since the occupation of Alexandria by the enemy, will shortly be resumed in the city of Richmond, and on an enlarged basis.
The best outfit which the times will allow has been secured, and is now being collected; and it is the intention of the parties associated in the enterprise to spare no pains or capital in the effort to publish a first class newspaper.

The "Sentinel" will have the good of the country as its controlling and animating aim; and will warmly sympathize with whatever is calculated to promote the happiness and prosperity of the people.
It will gladly had every good citizen as a colaboter.
It will be blased by no special interests.
It will have no individual ambition to subserve and no personal prejudices to indulge.
Independent of all, and just to all it will not knowingly bestow either undeserved censure or unmerited praise.
It will be ready to condemn when duty requires, and ready also to pay the grateful tribute due to exhibitions of virtue and capacity.

The first number of the "Sentinel," under its new auspices, will appear about the first of March--perhaps a few days sooner or later.
It is proposed, in addition to the daily issue, to publish semi-weekly and weekly papers, as soon as a sufficient number of subscribers is received to justify the latter issues.
To enable us to commence these at the same time with the daily, as we expect to do, we invite those disposed to subscribe to send in their names at once.
The terms of the Sentinel will be strictly in advance, and otherwise, as follows:
No paper, except the Daily, mailed for less than six months. Papers discontinued when the time paid for expires, unless the subscription be previously renewed.

The Sentinel office will be conducted under the partnership name of Smith, Bailey & Co.--The editorial management of the paper will be under the charge of R. M. Smith.
The business department will be conducted by A. M. Bailey.
Address
div3.closer:
Smith, Bailey & Co.,
Sentinel Office, Richmond, Va.
Richmond, February 7, 1863.
The office of the Sentinel will be in the spacious brick building lately occupied by Binford & Porter, corner of Franklin and Governor streets, opposite the Whig office, and near the Ballard House. fe 10--d3t aw&wlt

div3.head: For Hire.
div3.p:
--A Woman, of excellent character, as Cook in a private family.
She is without encumbrance.
Also, a Girl, for Dining-room Servant or Nurse, who is honest and can be recommended in every respect.
Call on Grace at, two doors above Adams.

div3.head: The revolution in the West.
div3.p:
--A special to the Advertiser and Register dated McMinnville, 11th, says into Northern papers show a great revolution in all the Western and border States.
The Louisville Journal says Lincoln is crazy or mad, and begs him to rescind his proclamation.
It further says their soldiers will not fight side by side with negroes.
The soldiers at Murfreesboro' have held a meeting and resolved to uphold the Democracy of their States.

div3.head: Beautiful Improved farm, near Charlottesville, and twelve or fifteen Negroes, for sale.
div3.p:
--In obedience to a decree of the Circuit Court of Albemarle, pronounced in the chancery suit of "Henderson and wife vs. Crawford and ," the undersigned Commissioners wills offer for sale, at public auction, on the premieres, on Tuesday the 3d day of March, 1863 (or the next fair day.) a beautiful estate, known as Meadow Clerk, containing about acres.
This farm lies within a mile of Charlottesville, and less than a mile from the University of Virginia; has an abundance of timber; is smooth and gently undulating, of a high degree of improvement; has a large creek passing entirely through the place, affording a quantity of fine meadow land, well act in old grass yielding a large quantity of hay; and there is a spring of running water in every field.
There is an excellent dwelling-house, and all the necessary out houses, and a fine peach orchard on the place.
It is seldom that so desirable a place, in the immediate vicinity of a large town, is offered for sale.
Will be send at the same time and place, 12 or 15 likely Negroes, Household and Furniture a fine Piano, two good Cows, &c.
Terms--Pretty much at the option of the purchaser.

--On Saturday the 14th inst, I will sell as Commissioner at the auction house of Lee & James, to this city, a likely Woman.
No. 1 field hand.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 24, Number 38, page 2.

div3.head: Remittances to the Dispatch.
div3.p:
--We have made arrangements with the Southern Express Company by which all money for subscription, advertising, or job work, can be sent at our risk.
The money to be sent should be enclosed to an envelope, directed to the "Richmond Dispatch, Richmond, Virginia," and seated with wax, writing the subscriber's name, post-office, and amount sent on the outside.
Deliver the same to any agents of the Southern Express Company, and take his receipt.
Send a letter to the office of the Dispatch by mail, advising us of the date when sent.
Our agents will observe carefully these directions, and follow them.

div3.head: Type wanted.
div3.p:
--The proprietors of this paper wish to purchase 1,000 or 1,500 pounds of Nonpareil or Agate Type.
The highest price will be paid.

div3.head: The enemy's designs.
div3.p:
"Fighting Joe Hooker" is still in Stafford, they say, but the question is, what movement does he contemplate next?. That he designs to make a movement as soon as the weather may prove sufficiently favorable, does not seem, to admit of a doubt.
Will be try the passage of the Rappahannock once more, in the face of Gen. Lee's army, or will be "change his base," and move on Richmond by way of the Peninsula, as McClellan did before him?
We hardly think that game will be tried over again.
McClellan's army, which is the same that Hooker now commands, were too glad to get away ever to come back by the same route.
Will he turn the river at its mouth, make Norfolk his base, and come upon us by the south side? --He will be too sure to find a lion in his path if he come in that direction.
Will he incline to the right, and cross the Rappahannock higher up!
He can not do it without finding Lee always in his front Besides, if he makes the attempt, he must defer it until the suns and winds of the spring shall have dried the roads, for as matters stand at present, if he should make it now his men will be swallowed up in the mud so deeply that it will be impossible to find them, unless he bore for them with a coal auger.

In the meantime "fighting Joe" is compelled to do something by the very terms of his bid for the leadership.
He told the committee how the destruction of Lee might have been compassed, and how he would have accomplished it had he been in command.
The committee took the hint, and gave him the command.
Of course, nothing less is now expected of him than a full accomplishment of his promise.
He said he would have seized a certain position in Caroline county--with which he was well acquainted — and from which he could have repelled with 30,000 men the assault of the whole Confederate army.
This is a magnificent boast, and Joe is bound to prove that it is something more than a boast.--He will not be allowed to fall back upon Washington, as some of the Yankee writers advised Burnside to do when he was beaten at Fredericksburg.
He will find a fire in his rear, compared to which that of which poor old Scott complained was a more taper light.
He had better make up his mind to encounter General Lee at once.
That General is waiting patiently for him to come on, and will be glad to see him whenever he may feel disposed to advance.
If he can get through the mud, we would advise him to order a movement in front at once.
There is always danger in delay.
In this particular case the danger arises from his own men. They are deserting daily, and, if all accounts be true, the disposition to desert is growing instead of diminishing.
The Yankee soldiers are willing to steal the niggers to incite them to insurrection, to put themselves on a level with them, but they cannot stand being made to fight side by side with them, in the same ranks.
Regarding the negro as much the better man of the two, we are unable to account for this repugnance; but that it exists is certain.

In the meantime we congratulate "fighting Joe" upon his initiation into the beauties of a Stafford and Prince William mud. They have been famous in the traditions of the stage-coach for a hundred years. The stage-coach is gone, but the mud "Is still there, " and so is the Yankee buzzard, or "old flag," as the Yankees call that emblem of defeat, disgrace, cowardice, meanness, rape, rapine, murder, and arson.
John Randolph made a speech in the House of Representatives once upon internal improvements, and had a deal to say about the mud of Choppowamsic, from which he had barely escaped with life on his way to the capital.
A part of "fighting Joe's" men are right in the midst of it. We wonder how they like it?

div3.head: The speculators.
div3.p:
The most complete excoriation which these sinners have ever received is in the late address of Rev. Dr. Stiles, on the subject of "National Rectitude the only true basis of National Prosperity." The speculators furnish a fruitful topic.
It is one which is as inexhaustible as their own greediness.
Like the daughters of the horse-leech, they raise an eternal cry of "Give!
give!" but, unlike leeches in general, they never feel full enough to drop off. All the denunciations they receive seem to whet their appetites, and the groans of their victims, like the whistling of the winter's wind to people seated around a comfortable fire, heightens their own enjoyments by the force of contrast.

A contemporary observes that mankind are always fond of considering themselves ill-used, and ever ready to lay the blame upon the wrong shoulders; which he illustrates by the outcry against speculators, when the really responsible parties, those whom we ought to abuse, are the Yankees.
This is certainly the keenest and bitterest thrust that those robbers and murderers have received during this war. We have heard a good deal of pleasant sarcasm at their expense, and have exhausted our own vocabulary of hard names long ago, but we knock under to our ingenious contemporary.
The Yankees responsible for the crimes of the speculators!
We thank our contemporary for discovering a new point of resemblance between the Yankees and the Devil.
The Devil, who has vileness enough of his own to answer for, is often charged by sinners with being the responsible agent in their rascalities, when he had just as little to do with them as the Yankees have with the price of wheat, corn, and potatoes!
No doubt many men are tempted by the Devil, but there are a good many first rate villains who require no temptation, and find him a great convenience in accounting for their transgressions.
The Yankees are monsters enough to starve us to death if they could, but they can't; whilst the speculators can and are doing it, and then lay the blame upon the Yankees!.

In sober carnest, the Yankees have no more to do with the enormous prices of articles of prime necessity than the man in the moon.
It suits the self-delusion of speculators to lay all their sins upon the Yankees, but there are no Yankees more mean, mercenary, and devilish, than the hypocritical wretches who are eternally bawling out "Yankees," to divert attention from their own robbery, murder and treason.
Those hideous crimes which Yankees practice upon their enemies in war, they practice upon their friends in peace — picking their pockets, starving them to death, and exposing the Southern cause to greater peril of destruction than the combined armies of Yankeedom.

If these faint compliments are quite inadequate to their merits, we recommend them to borrow Dr. Stilee's pamphlet, (buying it might involve the expenditure of half a dollar,) and read the just and terrible philipple upon their tribe which that pamphlet contains.
It begins at page 28 and ends at page 32. They needn't trouble themselves with any other part of the address, as the remainder is generally devoted to those classes of sinners who are not past praying for, and in that they can have no possible concern.
But we insist they shall read from page 28, beginning "The infernal greed of the speculator." to 32, ending, "Drowning his soul in perdition and destruction." It will be a great place of folly for them not to read what everybody else will, and to go about the streets with a label on their foreheads and a placard on their backs, which all their neighbors are staring and quietly laughing at, while they are not aware of its existence.--"Great, hungry shark of the ocean," as Doctor Stiles calls thee, go and behold thy beautiful likeness in these pages.
But we might as well expect a shark to feel misgivings about his conduct as the speculator. "The day approaches," says Dr. Stiles, "when it would seem that his atrocious operations, by necessary consequence, must ultimately cast our beloved country under the iron heel of the despot, and liberty and hope and all be crushed out forever.
And can be stand the diabolical thought of personal elevation upon his country's downfell!" Can he "feel no relenting pulsation?
Feel indeed!
This men is past feeling." His "cherished covetousness" has made him " a monster, " and anticipated wealth in the only world he lives in. "All rise to him is unreal.
An angry God is a picture; a gasping country is a dream; blasted character, a disgraced family, coming retribution — all, all, to him are harmless shadows.
There is no deed of darkness which the soul of the accomplished speculator is not primed and charged to accomplish.
That miserable man!
At such a time as this!
Yes, at such a time as this he can feed and fatten upon the tasked sinews of the Government — upon the struggling liberties of the people — upon the scanty wages of the soldier — upon the falling morsels of the poor — upon the last golace of the sick, the wounded, and the bereaved, and feel nothing. He can ponder all the brutal, crushing cruelties of Northern subjugation, and dwell upon all the swelling, bursting, maddening endurances, endurances of the Southern captive, and yet feel nothing.
The spirit of the South--that most beautiful, genial, admirable element of our national heritage — that Southern spirit so brave, generous, proud, and independent — he can look forth into the future and see that spirit — that noble spirit — by most unholy persecution crushed out of the people and lying a cold corpse over all these hills and valleys where once it lived so vigorous and happy an existence--yes, and feel nothing. Oh, yes!
He can gaze upon all this heart rending spectacle and feel nothing — nothing but the splendors of that fortune he sticks out of the last drop of his country's blood."

div3.head: To the Voters of Virginia.
div3.p: --Fellow-citizens: Having been requested by many of you to become a candidate for the office of Governor at the regular election in May next, I respectfully announce that I cheerfully yield to such request, and, in the event of my election, will diligently and to the best of my ability perform the duties of the position.

I am sensible of the responsibilities which I announce my willingness to assume.
I am painfully aware of the glant struggle which is in progress, and that it may be my duty to assume such responsibilities without counting the cost to myself.
In such event I shall unhesitatingly do so, only asking the liberal construction of my fellow-citizens for my vindication and defence.

I regret that it will not be in my power to appear among you and address you upon public affairs.
But, having deemed it my duty to adhere to the army, to which, after a confinement of some months, I am about to return, I shall not have an hour to spare for any other purpose.
I regret this the less, however, as I flatter myself that I am sufficiently well known to you in person, or by reputation, to enable you to exercise the sovereign power of suffrage with all proper intelligence.

With no parties to divide us — with but one great impulse — that which seeks to protect our liberties and establish our independence — we surely can work together with one will to realize this vital consummation.
At any rate, if elected, I shall seek to deserve your confidence by devoting to the duties of my position all the powers of mind and body which I possess.
Believing, if true to ourselves, that a gracious Providence will crown our righteous and glorious efforts with success, I have the honor to be, most respectfully and cordially, your fellow-citizen.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--I am informed that my man, John, who sometimes calls himself Jno Baker, or Jno Ligon, at others calls himself Joe, was taken up recently from the army near Fredericksburg, where he was employed as a cook, and sent to some of the public or private jails in the city of Richmond.
Any information furnished me in the county of Powhatan, Jefferson Post-Office, or to me at the American Hotel, No. 44, until Friday at 12 o'clock, will be liberally rewarded.
John is 23 years old, about 5 feet 2 or 3 inches high black, has a scar on his right or left arm occasioned by a burn.
He left my residence in July last, and I presume he has been with the army until he was apprehended.
The information I have leads almost to a certainly that he is now in the city of Richmond in jail.

div3.head: One hundred dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ranway from the subscriber, on Friday, January 16, 1863, a negro man named Griffin.
The said slave is about 28 years of age; dark brown skin; five feet four or six inches high, and his left arm smaller than his right, having been broken when young.
Griffin was formerly owned by Rob. Lowe, of Chapel Hill N. C., who sold him to J. Monroe Carter, of Richmond, Va., on the 6th of October, 1862.
I will give the above reward for the capture and return to me of said slave, or for his confinement in jail, so that I get him again.
div3.closer:
H D Dickinson, Rice's Depot,
Prince Edward co, Va. fe 13--3t*

div3.head: One hundred dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away from Wylliesburg, in Charlotte county, during the month of June, 1862, my man Bartlett.
For his apprehension and delivery to me, if taken up out of the State, I will pay the above reward; it captured within the State, and placed in jail so that I can get him I will pay $50. Bartlett is about 20 years of age, of small stature, weighing, perhaps, 130 pounds; 5 feet 5 inches high, mahogany color, one upper tooth out in front, low forehead, and dull countenance.
When last seen he was in the vicinity of Clarksville.

div3.head: Ranaway
div3.p:
--From my residence, in Powhatan county, on the 27th January, a negro Man named Jerry.
He is about 35 years old 5 feet high, front teeth out, and not very black skin; had on when he left a pair of wooden (maple) bottom shoes, ironed with hoop iron in four different pieces on each shoe.
A suitable reward will be given for his apprehension and delivery to me, or his confinement in jail.
It is thought that he is on the James river, though he may be elsewhere.

div3.head:
Freight Office R & D R R,
Richmond, Feb. 10, 1863.
special notice.
div3.p:
--Taken up at the depot of the Richmond and Danville Railroad, this day, a small negro boy, named John, who says he be longs to a Mr. Peter Burnley, from the country.--Said boy is about eight years old, and of a gingerbread complexion.
The owner will come forward, prove property, pay charges, and take him away.

closer.signed: P S Wren, R & D R R.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p: --For the war. One over 45 preferred, though no objection would be urged to a youth between 16 and 17, if robest, healthy and acceptable to the Government, Apply to

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--For one over forty-five years of age, who can come well recommended, a liberal price will be paid.
Call between 9 and 3 o'clock on Friday, the 13th, st,
div3.closer:
Mason & Yankcay's Shoe Stores,
113 Main st., bet. 13th and 14th. fe 13--1t*

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p: --One over 45 years of age, with perfectly responsible recommendations, can get a liberal price by applying at.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--I will pay a liberal price for an able-bodied man, over 45.
I may be seen at the office of Jeter & Harris, corner of Shoekoe Warehouse, opposite Columbian Hotel.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p: --Will pay $2,000 for an able-bodied man, over 45 years of age. Apply to
div3.closer:
C C Davis, Gen'l Hospital, No. 20,
Richmond. fe 13--2t*

div3.head: Three Substitutes wanted.
div3.p:
--A liberal price will be paid to sound and reliable men, over 45 years old, to go to Camp Lee.
Inquire at Room No. 50 American Hotel.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--Wanted, a Substitute, to go in a No. 1 artillery company.
None need apply unless he is over 45 years old, sound and healthy, and with a character well endorsed.
For such an one a liberal price will be paid.
A Virginian preferred.
Apply at the office corner of Wall and Franklin sts. to Clopton & Lyne.

div3.head: Two Substitutes wanted.
div3.p:
--Wanted two Substitutes to join the army for the war. The sum of $1,800 each will be paid.
They must be over 45 years of age, and come recommended.
Apply at Room 105 Spotswood Hotel, or at Donnan & Co's office, on Shockoe Slip.

div3.head: Married.
div3.p:
At the residence of Mr. Joe B. Stegal, on the 11th inst., by the Rev. Mr. Peterkin, Mr. H. B Pickett to Miss.
Rollis D Garthright, both of this city.

div4.p: At his residence, in New Kent county, on the 6th of February, after a short and painful, Illness, of congestion of the liver, Mr. Povall Turner, in the 52d year of his age.

He leaves a large family and many friends to mourn their loss.
He was a useful and valued member of society.
On Thursday morning the 12th of February, of . Allen Lyon, son of John K. and Kate T. Childrey, in the 5th year of his age.
His funeral will take place this (Friday) morning, at 11 o'clock, from the residence of Mr. Lewis H. Fraysers on 19th street. The friends of the family are invited to attend. *
At the residence of Thos. J. Hagby, on Thursday, the 12th inst., Mrs. Harriet Courtney, relict of the late Robert Courtney, of King and Queen county, aged about 60 years.
Her friends and acquaintances and those of the family are invited to attend her funeral this (Friday) afternoon, at 3½ o'clock.

Suddenly, on Wednesday morning at 15 minutes to 3 o'clock, of dropsy of the heart, Elizabeth G. Davis, consort of Thos. Davis.
Kind and affectionate in all the relations of life, she will be long mourned by a large circle of relatives and friends.
The funeral will take place from the First Baptist Church, this afternoon at 3 o'clock. The friends and acquaintances are invited to attend.
Petersburg Express please copy. *
In this city, on the 12th instant, at the residence of his sister, Mrs. Emily G. Jinkins, A B Timberlake, of Hanover county, in the 54th year of his age.
His friends and those of his sister are invited to attend his funeral from the residence of Mrs Emily G Jinkins, on Duval street, near 2d, to-morrow (Saturday) morning, at 11 o'clock. 2t*

div4.head: Obituary.
div4.p: Died, at Wolf Trap, the residence of James E Palmer, in the county of Halifax, on Monday the 9th inst, of scarlet fever, Sallie C, only child of Abner H Richardson, aged eight years and three months.

As an angel of light came Death and bore this little one to the portals of Heaven to rejoin her sainted mother, whose pure spirit God called to himself but three weeks previous.
Weep not for her, bereaved parent; know that the little flower you so fondly cherished and watched as it expanded from its infant germ now blooms in Heaven.
Your loved ones are among the blessed, and you shall see them again in a world where death and time shall be no more. [*] C.

div3.head: Wanted — Recruits.
div3.p:
--Having been authorized to raise a company, the same to be attached to Major Elliott's City Battalion (5th Va.) I invite the attention of Conscripts and others to this chance of joining a good company, for special duty in and around Richmond.
$50 bounty and good clothing given.
Quarters and rations furnished from day of enlistment.
Apply at once, at the Barracks, between 8th and 9th streets South side of the Basin.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--I wish to employ, immediately, a male Teacher, to take charge of a few children.
He must be qualified to teach Latin, French, and Marthematics, as well as the usual English branches.
Terms, not less than 200 per session, of ten months, and pro rata for a shorter time.
Address, immediately, giving reference,
div3.closer:
J T Goodwin,
Bowling Green, Caroline co., Va. fe 13--4t*

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A male Teacher thoroughly qualified to teach about 20 boys in the English branches, Mathematics, Latin, Greek, and French.
One of experience and desiring permanency preferred.
To a suitable man $300 or $800 and board will he guaranteed for ten months. Apply early to, or address.
div3.closer:
Thos J Perkins, Perkinsville,
Goochland county. Va. fe 13--2t*

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--immediately, a Carriage Trimmer.
Also, a Woodworker — The highest wages will be paid for good hands, and steady employment given.
Apply to
div3.closer:
John Boes,
Corner 9th and Broad streets.
Or at his Shop, 1st and Marshall sts. fe 13--2t*

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--By a gentleman and his wife, a Bed Room and two Kitchen Rooms.
If not in the same house it makes no difference, so that it is in one or two squares of each place — location on Main, Franklin, or Broad sts., above 18th, Address "Watchmaner," at Dispatch office.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--Three intelligent and competent gentleman, who desire commissions in the army, to recruit's company of Mounted Riflemen or Cavalry, under authority from the Secretary of War.
Address "Gappain." Box No. 118,

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A Virginia Lady, of some years experience, desires a situation as Governess, or to take charge of a small school.
She is competent to the higher English branches, together with Latin and French.
Address "J M H." box 527.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--One or two unfurnished Rooms with use of kitchen between 1st and 10th streets, and between Cary and Clay.
Part or whole of a small house preferred.
Address "B W J," Richmond P. O.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--A Teacher, to instruct two children in English, Latin and French.
Liberal arrangements will be made with a competent party, either male or female.
Address "J. H.," Dispatch office.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A situation by a young girl, to do Chamber Work and Plain Sewing for a private family.
Address "T. D." at this office.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A good Nurses, 15 hands high or thereabouts, for the cavalry service.
For a suitable one a good price will be paid.
Address Post Office Box 465"

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p: --A good Hostler, white or colored; also a good Porter, to remain ini the city.

closer.signed: Capt and A. Q. M, 25th Va. Batt'n.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A good Bread Baker, for which a good price will be paid.
Apply to M. V. Spicer, back of the New Market, next door to the Charleston House.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A Situation, by an exempt, who is familiar with the commission business and has an extensive acquaintance.
Address "L. S. M." Richmond P. O.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p: --One or two Rooms suitable for a doctor's office, on Main, between 10th and 17th sts. address immediately, "Doctor," Box. 105 Post Office.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--an Engineer to run a mill, a shout distance from the city.
Apply at Dr. Chas. E. Anderson's, corner of Clay and Foushes sts.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p: --$2,000 will be paid for a furnished House, with six or more rooms in it. Address

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--To purchase a good Washer Ironer, and House Servant.
Apply at Cary Street jail.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A situation as Bookkeeper.--A young man who has several hours of during the day, is desirous of occupying his time in writing up books and accounts.
He has had several years' experience as an accountain, writes a good hand, and can offer good reference.
Any one wishing to employ him will please address "J. H." Dispatch Office.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p: A Man of experience to engage in the manufacture of . Apply to
div3.closer:
B. P. Harrison,
At Royster Hospital. fe 11--3t*

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--An active Man, of good character &co or slave to act as Porter.
Apply to
div3.closer:
E. R. Roberts.
Corner Cary and 13th sts. fe 11--2t*

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--Immediately a Bread Baker.
Also, an intelligent young lady to assist in the store.
Apply to

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p: --At Madamo Son's, three first-rate Milliness and one Trimmer.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--By a lady of considerable experience, a Situation in any nice Confectionery, By Goods, or Fancy Stores.
Address "B. P." through the Richmond P. O.

div3.head:
Attention Marilanders!
Net wanted.
div3.p: Horses furnished and Equipments found.
I am authorised to recruit for Company D, White's Battalion of Cavalry, G. S. A.
This company is composed almost entirely of Marylanders, and is commanded by Jos Anderson, of Montgomery co., Md, I want from ten to Twenty Recruits to complete its organization.

It is unnecessary to speak of White's Battalion.
Its deeds speak for it. It has captured and killed over fifteen hundred Yankees and hundreds of dollars worth of property since its organization.
The of this Battalion is equal to that of any corps in the army.
All who want active service, plenty of fighting, plenty of plunder, and to serve under as gallant's commander as ever went upon a battle field, should join this corps.
div3.closer:
J. G. Gannon,
Virginia Hotel. fe 13--1t*

div3.head:
[extract]
Headquarters,
Richmond, February 7, 1862.
special Orders, no 27.
div3.p: IV. Brig-General Winder, commanding Department of Henrico, is charged with the duty of granting Passports beyond the lines of the Confederate army which will be given in such instances, and upon such conditions, as he may deem proper; subject, however, to the direction of the General in immediate command of the lines through which the applicant desires to pass.
div3.closer:
By command of Maj. Gen. G. W. Smith
Samuel W Melton,
Major and A A General. fe 9--3t

div3.head: Notice to Conscripts
div3.p: --The Medical Examining Board for the 3d Congressional District is now holding its session at the Camp of Instruction, near Richmond.
All persons of conscript age, who have been authorized to appear before this Board for final examination, will report immediately.

closer.signed: John A Coke, Capt and Enroll'g Officer

div3.p: All those who have enlisted with me will report at once to Lieut P P Johnston's Recruiting Office, on Main street, opposite the Post Office, or be considered at deserters.

Commissioner's sale of Land in Hanover county, 1½ miles from Hanover C. H, and one mile of the Virginia Central Railroad.--In to a decree of the County Court of Hanover, pronounced on the 24th day of December 1863, in the suit of Tally, &c, vs Wingfield, I shall proceed to upon the promises, on Wednesday, the 4th day of March next, the tract of Land in the hill mentioned containing about 240 Acres, adjoining the lands of J. S. Wingfield Wm. F. Wickham, B. Wingfield, and others, and is the place on which Jos. Wingfield, dec'd lately resided about 3½ miles from the Court House, and one mile from the Virginia Central Railroad, in the good repair and all necessary, out burning.
About one third of the land is cleared, a large portion of which is in low grounds.
Of the wood land a large portion is to original ground.
The on the land will more than pay
Terms--One-third the balance in 12 months, with interest from day of cala, or the whole in cash, at option of the purchase, the title to be retained until the order of the Courts.
